nodes.text: Replacing neural network segment classifiers with support vector machines (SVM) will improve handwritten numeral recognition performance and can be integrated into an SVM/HMM hybrid word recognizer
SVMs offer better generalization via structural risk minimization and large margin classification compared to empirical risk minimization used by neural networks
We implemented SVM classifiers for isolated character recognition using one-versus-rest multi-class strategy and SVM formulations from statistical learning theory

Feature extraction used moment invariants (7 original + 7 thinned = 14), affine moment invariants (4), and online spatially resampled local features resulting in 350 input feature values for SVM experiments
Datasets used include UCI Optdigits (8x8 and 32x32 formats), IRONOFF, UNIPEN, and a collected Assamese character dataset of 8235 samples from 45 writers
SVM experimental configuration: used RBF kernel for final experiments, performed grid search to select hyperparameters, and chose C = 8 and gamma = selected value
SVM classification runs were performed in training and testing phases with disjoint training and test sets; a test application was used to load Optdigits data and run analyses
Theoretical SLT argument: minimizing empirical error and model capacity (VC dimension) together via SRM yields better generalization, which underlies SVM design
SVM was applied as a binary classifier extended to multi-class by one-versus-rest and also described in linear and kernelized formulations to maximize margin and identify support vectors
Preprocessing and feature extraction pipeline: filtration, normalization, segmentation to character units, then feature computation (moments, affine invariants, resampled local features)
For image-based features 18 moment-related features were used for SVM; for online-resampled experiments each character produced 350 feature values as SVM input
Experimental result: the test application classification correctly identified 98% of the testing data (disjoint test set) using the described SVM setup
Comparative experiments across datasets show SVM outperforms Hidden Markov Model (HMM) on isolated character recognition in all three evaluated databases
Conclusion: SVMs are a promising solution for handwriting recognition and integrating SVM character classifiers into HMM-based word recognizers is expected to improve word recognition rates
Limitation: SVM models require substantially more parameter storage (memory proportional to number of support vectors times feature dimensionality) compared to HMM weight-sharing schemes
Mitigation and future work: reduce number of support vectors via finer C and gamma grid search and reduced set selection; implement hybrid SVM/HMM word recognizer with preprocessing and normalization
